Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Changing perceptions of causes and consequences in the immediate aftermath of a disaster

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research supported by this award will investigate how perceptions of a disaster are formulated in the immediate aftermath of the event. The researchers will investigate the proposition that social and economic position affects understanding of the disaster and thereby produces variable goals and plans for disaster mitigation and post-disaster reconstruction. Previous research has shown that disasters can reveal strengths and weaknesses in the behaviors influenced by social and cultural factors. In this project, the researchers explore how those revelations are produced in the immediate aftermath of making sense of what has happened and how they vary across different stakeholders. Findings will be disseminated to organizations that explore and manage the causes, consequences, and complexities of disaster management and recovery. Funding this research also trains students from underrepresented groups in social science research.

This RAPID award supports the collection of data in Houston using anthropological ethnographic methods. The researchers will conduct saturated interviewing of city officials involved in land use planning, disaster reduction, disaster response, and disaster recovery. A stratified (by socio-economic, racial, and other variables) sample of community leaders will be researched through participant observation and interviews. The objective is to document how perceptions vary, how they develop over time, and how they affect the eventual mitigation and prevention plans that are produced. The research will produce a baseline ethnographic map (an ethnographic narrative that connects the social production of space with the social production of social difference and disaster vulnerability) of Houston that identifies city residents' varied problematizations of the disaster. This will provide a database baseline for future research and for stakeholders.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For anthropologists, disasters are the result of interactions between people and their environments in which the latter engage in behaviors (e.g. land use and political practices, social inequality) that enhance the materially destructive and socially disruptive capacities of geophysical phenomena, technological "accidents," and communicable diseases. While catastrophic events are often seen as extraordinary events, the natural hazards (e.g. hurricanes, earthquakes) that set them off are not the disaster in and of itself. Most importantly, the human practices that convert a hazard into a disaster are often accepted as part of ordinary life. However, because of their related social disruption, environmental transformation, and material loss, some anthropologists have analyzed the catastrophic phases of disasters as opportune moments that shed light on the social dimensions of disasters and provide a window for critical reflection (and perhaps mitigation) on their root causes. It is for this reason that some social scientists have called disasters "revelatory crises."

The premise of our project was that, while catastrophes may reveal their root causes to social scientists who are well-versed on disaster vulnerability theory, they might not reveal the same things to the general public. We were therefore interested in interviewing a cross section of Houstonian society to elicit answers to our question "What does Hurricane Harvey reveal for you?" We were particularly interested in using responses to this question to develop a better understanding of the vantagepoints from which Houston's diverse residents interpreted Hurricane Harvey's effects, how that vantagepoint affected the ways they imagined the policies and practices necessary to reduce the severity or likelihood of similar catastrophes in the future, and whether their vantagepoint changed over time as a result of the catastrophe's effects. 

Our project relied on what we called a “purposive snowball” sampling technique. On the basis of existing census and demographic data for the city, we knew which parts of Houston were home to specific sectors of the population on the basis of ethnic/race identity and socio-economic status. We also knew which neighborhoods had sustained the heaviest flooding during Harvey. 

We began our sampling strategy by relying on public directories of civil society organizations like neighborhood and superneighborhood associations. Superneighborhoods are organizations formed by city government over a decade ago to facilitate communication between Houston’s residents and City Council. They are composed of a dozen neighborhoods each and their representatives meet on a monthly basis at the meetings of the Superneighborhood Alliance. The civil society leaders and organizers we contacted were helpful in connecting us with other residents who would be willing to speak about their experiences during Harvey and their interpretations of the disaster’s root causes. The results of our work revealed that Houstonians speak in a variety of different ways about Harvey’s root causes and that disasters are not merely “revelatory crises” but, instead, are multivocal interpretive phenomena. Most importantly, the ways our interlocutors narrated their interpretation of Harvey was heavily contextualized within their socio-economic positionality. Below, we briefly review the themes that emerged within each of the areas of Houston we conducted or work. 

The civil society leaders we interviewed (all of whom were college educated and some were quite affluent) interpreted Harvey from a perspective very similar to that of anthropologists well-versed in vulnerability theory. They saw the land use practices on the part of real estate developers as a primary culprit in altering the region’s hydrological system and floodplains. They also problematized the relationship between campaign contributions and city Mayors who appoint officials who have the power to grant exceptions to floodplain building codes. In East Houston, in contrast, we recognized the emergence of a religious theme in our interlocutors’ responses to our research question. In this instance a number of working class African American respondents explained the root cause of Harvey as “God’s will.” Subsequent ethnographic interviews and participant observation activities led us to conclude that this narrative is a discursive resilience strategy devised by members of communities with a long history of experiencing the arbitrariness of structural racism and environmental injustice. Residents of southwester neighborhoods like Manchester, on the other hand, expressed a concern with the invisible and unacknowledged disaster of toxic emissions produced by petrochemical plants. Finally, representatives of the city’s construction and real estate sectors attempted to minimize the impacts of Harvey and insisted that the city faced not so much risk of flooding, but the risk that an emphasis on flood risk reduction could inhibit capital reproduction and urban “development.” Our research also revealed that environmentally-conscious civil society leaders are concerned that, in the aftermath of Harvey, city government does not count with the resources necessary to enforce floodplain construction codes and that existing regulation, when poorly enforced, will only enhance existing flood risk.
